question_text: Which visual field defect is characterized by loss of vision in the upper quadrant of the visual field?

options.A: Contralateral superior quadrantopia

question_text: Which of the following has a large effect on Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD)?

options.A: Optic nerve

question_text: Hydroxyamphetamine drops help differentiate between which conditions?

options.A: Preganglionic from postganglionic

question_text: In a patient with ipsilateral scotoma and contralateral quadrantanopia, where is the localization of the lesion? (Describes junctional scotoma variant)

options.A: Occipital lobe

question_text: Examination of patients with anisocoria using hydroxyamphetamine eye drops helps in the diagnosis of?

options.A: Pre and post ganglionic lesion
Hydroxyamphetamine causes dilation of the pupil by releasing norepinephrine from the postganglionic neuron.
young patient presents with one eye visual loss followed by hearing loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
Branch retinal artery occlusions and sensorineural hearing loss
options.C: Episodic memory loss and personality changes

question_text: In the case of the largest relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), which structure is primarily affected?

options.A: Optic nerves

question_text: In the case of giant cell arteritis, what is the next step in management?

options.A: Steroid therapy
patient presents with eye pain that worsens with movement. Which of the following conditions could be the cause?

question_text: In an embryological problem of the optic chiasm, what finding would you expect to see in the examination?

options.A: Optic ataxia

question_text: In a scenario of Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy (LHON), what diagnostic tests would you consider to assess complications of this condition?

options.A: ECG
patient had left eye heterotopia and skew deviation, tilting to the right. Where is the lesion?

question_text: What is the most common cause of trochlear nerve palsy?

options.A: Trauma

question_text: What is the most common cause of trochlear nerve atrophy?

options.A: Infarction

patient with Horner syndrome did not respond to either hydroxyamphetamine or cocaine. What is the most likely location of the lesion?

question_text: In a case of optic neuritis in the right eye, which of the following findings is consistent with the condition?

options.A: Prolonged P100 in the right eye
options.B: Prolonged P100 in the left eye
options.C: Shortened P100 in the right eye
options.D: Shortened P100 in the left eye

options.A: patient presents with Horner's syndrome that does not react to cocaine or amphetamine. What type of lesion is indicated?

Fundoscopic examination shows cotton wool exudates and an elevated ESR. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
patient with ptosis is evaluated with Hydroxyamphetamine. What does this test differentiate?
young lady presents with proptosis, ptosis, complete ophthalmoplegia, and decreased sensation in V1 and V2. What will you do?

45-year-old female presented with visual blurring and is diagnosed with Brun's nystagmus. Brun's nystagmus is characterized by low-frequency, large-amplitude horizontal nystagmus when looking toward the side of the lesion, and high-frequency, small-amplitude nystagmus when looking away from the lesion. The large-amplitude nystagmus is caused by compression of which structure?

question_text: What is the artery associated with a left sectoranopia sparing the horizontal meridian?

options.A: MCA
patient with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) complains of visual issues, and examination shows retinal problems (Terson syndrome). Where is the issue for vision?
patient came with right optic atrophy and left papilledema. Where is the localization of the mass?

question_text: In a scenario of idiopathic intracranial hypertension, what can you see on brain MRI?

options.A: Empty Sella
patient is worse when he looks down to the left, with intact horizontal gaze and no other neurological symptoms. What is the localization of the issue?
patient with right relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) and right homonymous hemianopia; where is the lesion?
patient had optic neuritis in the right eye. What is the finding in the visual potential test?
young male with Kearns-Sayre syndrome presents with weakness and progressive ophthalmoparesis, with no family history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
case about a male with external ophthalmoplegia and ptosis, with onset before he was 10 years old. What is the diagnosis?

young adult has progressive bilateral painless decrease in visual acuity over 2-3 years. His brother had similar symptoms a few years ago. What should be tested in this patient? (Case of Leber’s disease)

question_text: Patient came with Leber optic neuropathy; what is your next step?

options.A: ECG
options.C: Genetic testing for mitochondrial DNA mutations

question_text: Which of the following infections can cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)?

options.A: Tuberculosis (TB)

question_text: Where is the location of popping nystagmus?

options.A: Pons

question_text: Which condition is improved with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors?

options.A: Apathy

question_text: What is the most common psychiatric manifestation of Wilson's disease?

options.A: Psychosis

question_text: Which antipsychotic medication has the highest risk of weight gain?

options.A: Olanzapine
patient with behavioral changes is sent to psychiatry initially and then to neurology. What is the next step in management?
delirious patient presents to the emergency department. What is your next step?

question_text: Anxiety most commonly complicates which of the following diseases?

options.A: Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD)

question_text: Which of the following antipsychotic medications causes the most weight gain?

options.A: Olanzapine

question_text: In Alzheimer's disease, which antipsychotic medication is known to increase weight?

options.A: Clozapine

question_text: In a case of Gerstmann syndrome, what is the associated language deficit?

options.A: Anomia

question_text: What is the primary characteristic that differentiates apraxia of speech from dysarthria?

options.A: Muscle weakness

question_text: After a traumatic brain injury (TBI), a patient wakes up apathetic. Which part of the brain is likely affected?

options.A: Frontal lobe

options.A: Flight of ideas

question_text: Which of the following is a common psychiatric manifestation in Wilson's disease?

options.A: Mania

question_text: An elderly patient presented with a visual field defect but denied having left homonymous hemianopia. A CT brain scan was performed. What is the explanation for her issue?

options.A: Visual anosognosia

question_text: Which of the following antipsychotic medications has the highest affinity for D2 dopamine receptors?

options.A: Olanzapine
soldier who was driving a military tank that exploded has some injuries, but two of his friends died. He dreams at night, feels guilt, and wishes to leave the army. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: An elderly patient presents with symptoms of delirium, showing decreased attention but no focal neurological signs. A CT scan of the brain and metabolic panel including CBC and U&E are normal. What is the next step in management?

options.A: Urine analysis and culture
options.C: EEG to assess for subclinical seizures
options.D: Review medications for possible delirium-inducing agents

options.A: middle-aged male presented to the outpatient clinic with his father, who stated that the patient had changed in the last few months. He is slower in cognitive function and has recently changed in personality, becoming easily agitated. He has a past history of a motor vehicle accident 3 years ago that resulted in 3 days of ICU admission. What is the appropriate next step?

bus driver has a seizure and requests that you do not inform his employer about the seizure. What will you do?

patient on pregabalin, suspected of drug abuse, is evaluated. What should you do?

patient with Parkinson's Disease on treatment presents with visual hallucinations and agitation. Which antipsychotic will you give?

options.A: Add Rivastigmine

newly diagnosed Huntington's disease patient states that he does not want to inform his employer. What should you do?

question_text: In Balint syndrome, which one of these clinical pictures is one of the presentations?

options.A: Simultagnosia

question_text: What is the management of functional tremor?

options.A: Propranolol

question_text: Which of the following findings is in favor of a diagnosis of functional tremor?

options.A: Distraction of the patient improves the tremors
options.B: Tremor frequency remains constant regardless of posture
options.C: Tremor amplitude increases with voluntary movement

question_text: In a patient with Wernicke's aphasia, which of the following symptoms is most commonly observed?

options.A: Fluent but nonsensical speech with poor comprehension
options.B: Nonfluent, effortful speech with good comprehension
options.C: Difficulty in repeating words despite intact comprehension
options.D: Loss of motor coordination and muscle weakness

options.A: patient presents with a right occipital lesion and visual field defect. What condition could be associated with this finding?
patient presented with a history of tingling sensation, numbness, and paresthesia, indicating small fiber neuropathy. He has pale bands over his nails. What is the likely diagnosis?

question_text: An HIV patient presents with a seizure. What is the likely culprit medication?

options.A: Efavirenz
patient with resected breast cancer who received radiotherapy developed Horner's syndrome and plexopathy. What is the underlying mechanism?

lady with a history of lung cancer, treated with radiation therapy 6 months ago, presents with 2 months of shoulder discomfort, weak shoulder abduction, and elbow flexion. NCS/EMG showed fibrillations in her hands and forearm muscles. What should be done next?

question_text: What is the recommended treatment for severe arsenic poisoning?

options.A: Supportive care
tuberculosis (TB) patient started on treatment and then had a seizure. What medication is causing the seizure?

question_text: What is the most common side effect of lithium?

options.A: Seizures

question_text: What medication causes sensory ataxia?

options.A: Pyridoxine

question_text: What is the medication that causes neuropathy and myopathy?

options.A: Dapsone

patient receiving intrathecal methotrexate presents with clinical and biological findings typical for subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. What else would you give the patient besides stopping methotrexate?

question_text: What medication can cause a positive Romberg sign and a scenario suggestive of sensory neuronopathy?

options.A: Pyridoxine
patient on anti-TB agents developed seizures. Which of the following agents can cause it?

question_text: Naloxone

options.B: Is a benzodiazepine used to treat seizures
options.C: Is a stimulant used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
options.D: Is an anticholinergic used to treat Parkinson’s disease

question_text: Flumazenil

options.A: Is used to treat opioid overdose
options.B: Is primarily used as an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose/sedation reversal
options.D: Is used to manage status epilepticus

options.A: patient with HIV on HAART developed seizures. What is the most likely cause?

question_text: Which of the following agents can cause sensory ataxia, vibration, and proprioception loss?

options.A: Pyridoxine
